manual intervention, or if the CMS is accidentally mutating dates...

From: London 2012 [mailto:openweekend@communicate.london2012.com] 
Sent: 10 February 2010 10:24
To: James Powell
Subject: Open Weekend 2010 - Registration opens today!

 

 



 Open

 

 

SJlFrKFs/> 

















Registration for London 2012 Open Weekend starts today!

Open Weekend supported by BP is back for 2010
London 2012 invites you to take part in Open Weekend 2010, on 23-25
July. Join us to celebrate two years to go until the Olympic and
Paralympic Games!

Last year over 470 organisations hosted 800 events across the UK; 90% of
organisations surveyed said their event attracted new audiences. Watch
the 2009 celebrations

SJlFrKFs/> 

Be part of Open Weekend in 2010 and celebrate with hundreds and
thousands of people across the UK. This year we are inviting Local
authorities, sporting and cultural organisations and venues across the
UK to set a challenge for the public to participate in. The challenge
could be to create a new piece of art in 24 hours, organise a treasure
hunt or stage a mass aerobics session - it's entirely up to you.

Who can be involved?
London 2012 Open Weekend is open to organisations and venues from the
world of culture and sport. We ask that your event:
- Sets a challenge that the public can participate in 
- Takes place between 23-25 July 2010 
- Is non-commercial and not-for-profit
- Does not have any commercial sponsorship or offer any similar
marketing rights 
- Is open to everyone

How to register your event 
To find out more about this fantastic weekend and to register an event
visit london2012.com/openweekend

SJlFrKFs/> . Registration will close at 12 noon on 16 July 2010. 

Workshops
We will be holding workshops across the UK on how you can get involved
in Open Weekend. Workshops will be held in:
Birmingham - 25 February 
Leeds - 16 March
Bristol - 22 March
Southampton - 26 March
London - 13 April

To book a place on one of the workshops or for any queries regarding
Open Weekend please contact us at openweekend@london2012.com
 .

Best wishes,

The London 2012 Open Weekend team
london2012.com/openweekend

SJlFrKFs/> 

















 





For information about how we handle the data we collect about people,
view our Privacy Policy

SJlFrKFs/> . The same principles apply to the data collected pursuant to
this newsletter.

Liz (this came out of getting the Velodrome 'splash' page live with Alex)

Rather than hacking the HTML of the 'splash' page (was 1000 days page) which results in lots of problems / inability for editors to edit it.
http://www.london2012.com/splash/index.html

We wondered if it would make sense to move it into the CMS as an editorial page that you guys can edit / assign pictures and links to in future.

Would probably take a short morning to get done, but would be there for future use.

Obviously it doesn't need to doing now, but if you think it a good idea / want to sign it off please do so ;-)

Jamie
I think it's a great idea!  Only I'm quite certain we're going to change our splash page template in the future, as this one really isn't 'on brand' any more.  So hold that thought....
Jamie, I'm guessing you've set the due date because of Alex's request for a new home page for next week. If so, it might be worth changing the priority to 'high' and billing to 'bill to oda'.
Tackled elsewhere as part of the velodrome lauch splash page

Hi Liz,

I responded to Morag's ticket on this earlier..
http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/795

To-recap what I said over in that ticket.

- In terms of spoofing emails, we only allow one email to be sent per
IP address per hour (actually you may be able to send more than one if
you use web01 and then web02 up to a maximum of 6 if you managed 
by a massive stoke of luck to hit web01-06 in sequence).

- In terms of 'injecting rogue code' / 'beign insecure' we strip out any HTML mark up
(or rather escape it) and the email is sent as a plain text so no
email client should be rendering the HTML? So not sure where the "Apparently it's not secure" comes from?

Although I do agree that if the service isn't being used much and you
would rather play it safe (and obviously the less points of attack the
better) then it may be sensible to remove it completely.

However this does leave the question of what goes in the place of it?

Should we just move the Share on Regit/Digg/Stumble links up the 3rd
column and leave the rest of the space on the right empty of now?

Obviously there is going to be a small amount of work (1-2 hrs) involved in re-coding that markup / CSS / republishing pages etc. (and as far as I am aware what is there at the moment is not inherently insecure, although as I said I do understand why you may prefer not to have it as a possible point of attack if it's not really used) never the less I think we probably will have to charge for  time spend removing it or re-jigging the CSS/markup.

Let us know if your happy to go with the suggestion above of dropping the email box and moving the digg/stumble links up to a 3rd column.

thanks

Jamie

Ah, sorry Jamie - I hadn't realised Morag sent this through!

 

But yes, I think that moving the digg/reddit/stumbleupon to the third
column is the best option! 

 

Thanks,

 

Liz

Hi.  This is high priority and I notice it isn't assigned to anyone.  Can someone please take a look??
Jamie, looks like you've got the Open W/E stuff on your plate for now. Sorry!

Liz, 1) Character encoding: this looks like an issue with the way Excel is importing the file. If I open it in in a text editor (or my version of Excel) it's fine. The file is in UTF-8 format if that helps in setting up your Excel (although fairly sure that is the default format / should be auto detected) 2) & Is this really causing serious issues? As I understood it the export was 'a quick way for the events team to see an overview all the events in one spreadsheet'. Because of this we're just outputting the XML we have stored internally (and in XML you can't store a raw & it has to be a &) We can run some reg-ex's but due to the way each field is output in a separate statement this is non-trivial (ie. it's not a flag or a single re-ex we need to add) 3) Spaces Once again what your seeing is the XML address node with the
's stripped out (leaving the text butted up). As mentioned above, we thought the purpose of this export was 'a quick way for the events team to see an overview all the events in one spreadsheet'. If we need to further format it fro Excel then there is additional work involved in doing this. 4) Postcodes We have a check in place to make sure it is between 4 and 10 chars (not sure how long it has been in place) Jamie

1) i will recommend that
2) it makes them grumpy - they distribute it to third parties, i think
3) they had the same problem last year with spaces/formatting. i think it's just not terribly user friendly. if you think it's going to be lots more work, please quote against it, but they may push back.
4) i'll let them know it's working...it clearly wasn't at some point, so we just won't be able to retro-fit.

 _____

Hi Liz,

OK we're had a little more of a play around (this is just the custom OW export, not the normal Event export; which I think should actually be fine / free of these issues)

One other thing to mention (which might help to add context to the comments below) we are creating a CSV (comma separated values) file *NOT* an Excel spreadsheet (which is a proprietary format). Therefore a lot of these issues are problems with the way Excel handles CSV exports and not the export itself.

That said I think we've fixed the two main issues, the Character encoding is a bit tricker as it;s outside out control.

1) Character encoding / strange characters:

The file is actually fine (open it in Notepad) the issue is that Excel is trying to read it in using a different character set (I expect windows 1252 or iso-8859-1) when it should be recognising it as UTF-8.

It's really an issue with Excel (sorry passing the buck !)
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/451636/whats-the-best-way-to-export-utf8-data-into-excel
http://www.myintervals.com/forum/discussion/280/making-csv-data-exports-with-utf8-more-excel-friendly/

We could (in theory, but maybe not in practice) export it using a different character set, but because we (like 99.9% of the web) use UTF-8 it may be a bit odd to start exporting some files using a different character set [UTF-8 is about as standard as you can get, so Excel really shouldn't have an issue with it; even if it does].

What's the solution:

- Newer versions of Excel don't seem to have this issue and support UTF-8 properly
- Open it in another program on windows and then save-as on it (might work)
- Open it in Google spreadsheets and then export it

We could export it as XML but only the newest versions of Excel support this.

2) &s;

Fixed

3) Spaces and line breaks

We've fixed spaces, line breaks are a bit tricker (once again due to how Excel handles them in CSV files) but we have replaced them with a space where appropriate.

Thank you! All totally sensible.
